text: Modulation of endogenous <extra_id_0> IL-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-1 receptor antagonist <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> results in opposing effects on HIV expression in chronically infected monocytic cells .
A proportion of HIV-infected individuals experience episodes of localized or systemic bacterial infections caused by Gram - negative bacteria .

Many of the clinical side effects of these infections are associated with the production of proinflammatory cytokines , which are induced primarily by LPS , a constituent of the bacterial cell wall of Gram - negative bacteria .
The present study examines the mechanisms involved in LPS - mediated induction of HIV expression in U1 cells , a promonocytic cell line chronically infected with HIV .

Stimulation of U1 cells by LPS alone induced minimal levels of HIV expression , which was significantly enhanced by <extra_id_0> granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

Costimulation of U1 cells with LPS plus <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> resulted in the accumulation of steady-state levels of HIV RNA ; however , only a weak induction of HIV long terminal repeat - driven transcription , which was not associated with the activation of the cellular transcription factor nuclear factor-kappa B , was noted .

Costimulation of cells with LPS plus <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induced the production of proinflammatory cytokines , <extra_id_0> IL-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: <extra_id_0> IL-1 receptor antagonist (ra) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibited LPS enhancement of HIV expression in <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - stimulated cells , suggesting that endogenous IL-1 was involved in LPS - mediated viral production .

In this regard , anti-inflammatory cytokines inhibited LPS plus <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - stimulated HIV expression , and this effect closely correlated with inhibition of <extra_id_0> IL-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> release and , in particular , with up-regulation of endogenous <extra_id_0> IL-1ra <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .

text: Thus , the balance between an endogenously produced viral inducer ( <extra_id_0> IL-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and an inhibitor ( <extra_id_0> IL-1ra <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) may represent an important pathway leading to modulation of HIV expression from monocytic cells .
